Definition: Given a sentence, your responsibility is to classify it into two different classes, which are insult and non-insult. Classify as an insult if the sentence expresses any language that is rude or abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: "Southern Democrats insisted on protecting slavery in all the territories while many Northern Democrats resisted. The party split over the slavery issue in 1860 at its Presidential convention in Charleston, South Carolina.
Northern Democrats nominated Stephen Douglas as their candidate, and Southern Democrats adopted a pro-slavery platform and nominated John C. Breckinridge in an election campaign that would be won by Abraham Lincoln and the newly formed Republican Party. After the Civil War, most white Southerners opposed Radical Reconstruction and the Republican Party's support of black civil and political rights.
The Democratic Party identified itself as the "white man's party" and demonized the Republican Party as being "Negro dominated," even though whites were in control." (PBS)
Placing the 2017 Democratic party into 1850 America is a fool's quest. 
Why can't Republicans stick with today? Because there's no arguing it's become hate-filled, racist, and fascist.

Comment: LLucas: "But this is not a cause and effect issue."
.
Actually, it is.
.
Countries with better governance are more prosperous.  The correlation is extremely strong, and has been true for centuries.
.
Wise government is economically efficient.  Again, this is a principle of the law-and-economics approach to governance, and it is borne out by centuries (indeed, millennia) of human experience.
.
The great source of our prosperity is the quality of our democratic institutions.  Those institutions have value beyond measure.
.
Nations that have good environmental laws do so because they have effective governance.  The environmental laws require internalisation of negative externalities, which makes those economies richer.
.
It is almost entirely an issue of cause and effect.
.
.
.
"Harper was right. And he is still right."
.

Comment: High income earners pay the lions share of all taxes so it is inevitable that anything that reduces taxes will disproportionately benefit higher income earners.

Put another way, if someone is only paying $20/year in total income taxes, the most you can possibly cut their taxes by is $20, or a 100% decrease.  If someone else is paying $10,000/year in taxes and you cut their taxes by $200 they benefited 10 times as much as the first person even though they only saw a 2% decrease in their taxes.

The notion that we can't have any programs that help reduce the tax burden just because those programs might benefit high income earners more is completely misguided and ignorant.

Comment: Since the author didn't really bother to answer the question seriously, I'll take a stab at it. 

Legally, if you smoke marijuana in your yard and it wafts into your neighbour's yard, that's a "nuisance" in the legal sense. Is it actionable as such? Possibly. If it interferes with your neighbour's reasonable enjoyment of his property, then yes he could sue you over it.

More practically, I think this is going to have to be handled by municipalities the way that other common nuisances are handled - through bylaws. As it stands many municipalities have already outlawed through bylaw open air burning. In Toronto, for instance, you can't have a fire pit in  your backyard, although cooking appliances are exempted.

As I see it, similar rules could come into force if marijuana use becomes a serious nuisance.

Comment: When our son was in elementary school I was a part time teacher's aide at a high risk demographic school in Wheat Ridge. Close to 70% free lunch participation. The school also had a snack cart during lunch periods. It was so discouraging to see a large majority of kids dump good quality lunches in the trash and head to the snack cart with rolls of dollar bills. I know their parents as well- some were well meant but many were just complete slackers, and that went for whites and Latinos, we did not have many black students. Yes, culture is significant but so is income and education. For both those who would like to do better and for those who abuse the system food stamps are just a bad idea. Why not put that money into food warehouses where families could shop for good basics, and perhaps take courses in cooking and nutrition and maybe even have exercise classes? Recipients could also help run the places, learning valuable skills. 1 in 7 hungry and 20% obese? Something needs to change.

Comment: Dave writes: “CPI has jumped 1.6 per cent in the first four months of 2017, the most inflationary four-month stretch in three years”, which is not true. This was the four-month rate of change for April 2017, but the same rate of change can be found for May and June 2016 and in May 2021 it was 2.1%. Making comparisons for different months of the calendar year for the CPI series unadjusted for seasonal variation is a dubious practice anyway. For the seasonally adjusted series the four-month inflation rate for April was just 0.6%, much less than the January 2017 rate of 1.2%. For the old CPIX core inflation rate the four-month rate of change for April 2017 was 1.2%, the same as in June 2016 but much less than the 1.7% rate in May 2016. For the seasonally-adjusted CPIX series the four-month rate of change was just 0.4%, less than the 0.5% change in January to March 2017.

Comment: The failure to have had an oil spill does not mean it won't happen.
Oil spills could be like earthquakes - the longer you go without one, the more certain it will happen soon.
If the Trans Mountain pipeline goes through, precautions must include a real time tanker traffic monitoring system that tracks every single tanker, and other cargo ship, in the Salish Sea and Strait of Juan de Fuca. All the ships must be equipped with all possible safety gear. The gear must be transmitting to mainland traffic supervisor sites at all times, including live video feed from the bridge and sensors on steering and engines.
Combine that with shore monitoring facilities that also do real time tracking radar of all cargo ships in these waters.
Combine that with capable tugs on standby along the route.

Comment: Wow, great investigative work and report.  I always knew it cost more to collect and disseminate recyclables and everyone does it for the right reasons.  However, given the economics we should probably nix the curbside program and opt for H-power, while continuing to collect from large commercial operations where there may be better economies of scale, such as hotels and businesses.  That way we can keep some recyclables in the loop.  As for individual households the city needs to provide a more efficient and convenient way to bring in recyclables so people don't end up spending more in gas and time than they get from bringing their bottles and cans in.  An example would be like Oregon where you can bring your bottles and cans right into the supermarket where you purchased them and get a discount on what your buy on the way out.  Simple, one trip, efficient and makes too much sense for our political "followers" to deliver.

Comment: I study the philosophy of science (including the logic and history) informally, and although I know this commentary is well-intended, its incoherence does the cause of science no favors.

If people want to march to call attention to climate change, great. If people want to march to prevent reductions in federal support for the enterprise of science (to save science jobs in the process), great. But don't imply that the denial of science has a political orientation. People like that are found all over the political spectrum. Most people who subscribe to left-of-center views deny biological influences on human behavior just like the religious right does. See "the blank slate" theory of human behavior. They insist, contrary to all findings, that society is responsible for personal behavior. This is why so much social policy of the last half century has been a failure--talk about denial of science and its impact on people.

Comment: Investment in commercial real estate is not a recent phenomenon. 

Even "mom and pop" investors have to raise rents; I think this article is referring to people who bought multi family properties decades ago for much lower prices. I'd wager a bet that when they originally purchased the building their rent was "high" for that time period. Point being, prices are relative to rents-no one can buy an apartment building at this time, then afford to rent it out for below market rents. That's because apartment buildings are priced based upon net operating income/ a given cap (return) rate (income approach), so if rents go up, so does the price tag.

Comment: 2/3
Lost in the dust up over the executive order are several important facts:
Persons applying to come to the United States are already subject to careful scrutiny. It takes at least two years to complete the process. Trump has never articulated what he means by “extreme vetting” and has never indicated what he would do differently from what is being done now.  I don’t think anyone believes that he has any plan beyond blocking Muslims.  No-one from any of the countries he has targeted has ever committed an act of terror in the United States; the countries from which terrorists have in fact come to the United States are not on the list.
The president has broad authority over immigration policy, and Trump may eventually win in court -- but only if he can sustain the fiction that he is not attempting to ban Muslims qua Muslims.

Comment: James Green, You referenced the precautionary principle in your previous comment that was removed because it did not meet civility standards.  As I mentioned, the precautionary principle is that if an action or policy has a suspected risk of causing harm to the public, or to the environment, in the absence of scientific consensus (that the action or policy is not harmful), the burden of proof that it is not harmful falls on those taking that action.  Therefore, the burden is on the GMO food producers to prove that GMO foods are not harmful to humans.  Or do you no longer subscribe to the precautionary principle?

Comment: It's not a terrible point. As another example, why don't we see any outrage over the India pale ale?  After all, it was literally invented so that imperialists could get drunk on British-made beer (in turn, presumably, making things rather more unpleasant for the Indians).

Anyway, I think the point is that it should be possible to appreciate the flavors and other byproducts of newfound cultural mingling without approving of the context associated with that mingling per se. That doesn't mean we should turn a blind eye to the crimes of imperialism, but neither should we reject foods and arts outright on account of their cultural parentage. It's a tricky balance to be sure, but maybe it's at least worthy of a conversation.

Comment: You are correct in implying that good scientists ARE skeptics.  However "skeptic" does not mean dismissing the overwhelming implications of data that's been collected globally, for decades, and subjected to rigorous peer-reviewed analysis.  Skepticism means saying "hmmm, that's an interesting hypothesis, prove it." An unprecedented rate of global warming due to an unprecedented rate of anthropogenic greenhouse gases spewed into the atmosphere has long been proved, for all practical purposes.  The remaining uncertainties revolve around how much, how fast, and how the effects will manifest themselves.

Yes, informed and measured skepticism should always be encouraged.  But seeking refuge in "skepticism" simply to avoid dealing with the obvious is irresponsible.

Comment: I find it interesting that neither respondent asked if there was any reason given by the employer for the termination of employment.  The assumption seems to be that the employer simply cannot terminate someone who is pregnant.  The laws around maternity/child care leaves are not designed to hold an employer hostage.  If there is another LEGITIMATE reason for ending employment, then the employer can act accordingly.  If the employee believes that the only possible reason for termination is her pregnancy, then by all means she should access the legal system including the Human Rights legislation applicable in her jurisdiction.  Also, she should not sign any release until this is resolved satisfactorily.  She may well have signed the release to access the severance payment, which other than for statutory amounts could be delayed significantly while each side is involved in the legal process.  The moral here  - don't sign off and expect a complaint to be heard later.

Comment: Why would someone leaving a driveway be cause for endangering life or inflicting serious physical injury? There has been no reason given that the individual was dangerous to the public if not "arrested without delay".  

Keep in mind that AS11.81.371(a) requires that the officer "reasonably believes" the individual may endanger life or inflict serious physical injury.  No evidence has been given that the officer(s) had any belief that the individual was an immediate danger to the public.

If in fact the officer(s) had "reasonable belief" he might endanger life or inflict serious physical injury, the basis for that reasonable belief should be made public.  

If the officers are claiming self defense (most likely) the basis for the use of lethal force in self defense should be public.

We're all responsible for this situation.

Comment: The chipping away at civility should deeply concern us, and not just because it isn't polite. It should concern us because, historically, civility is bound with order in public discourse and when it is discarded there is an inevitable downward-spiraling effect. 

The darker impulses within some human beings are only kept in check when society expects a certain level of courtesy and decorum in public life. But when leaders set an example of incivility, even if just for show, it gives these people the wink and nod they need to come out of the shadows. Once in the open, they easily find each other and mob mentality takes over.

This is what Trump must take ownership of. He may think of his undisciplined rhetoric and bombast as mere theatrics, but his more hateful supporters don't. He needs to understand that his words, whether sincere or not, have consequences. 

But I don't think he gets that and I'm not convinced he has the capacity to learn. That is what scares me the most.

Just as there are degrees of regular assault - assault, assault with a weapon, attempted murder - so should there be levels of sexual assault. A woman who drinks too much, passes out, can't remember whether or not she gave assent is very different from a woman who wakes up in her own bed with an intruder raping her and holding a knife to her throat. In the former case, the woman bears a degree of responsibility for her own behaviour. In the latter, she will be scarred for life, perhaps never again able to sleep properly. How society reacts to these incidents - and the vast number of assaults between these two extremes - should be different.

Comment: Here's one quick solution:    Give regular users of Transit a price break.    When the TTC sold MetroPasses, the pricing structure was not thought out.     In order to get full value, a user would need to make 12 trips per week.   Many work commuters only make 10.     Yet with the MetroPass, you pay up front for the month.    IF the TTC had offered a discount (eg:  make the breakeven 10 trip) they would have sold a lot more.    If you subscribed to the annual plan you should have received an even bigger discount as your subscription and revenue is fixed for the year.      A real failure in marketing by the TTC.

The new "Presto" system has promise - in that you can top up the card and then then use as needed - so it's great for convenience.     Here is the problem:   There are no Presto machines in some stations and on many buses.    So even if you buy a Presto card, you will still need to carry change or tokens for those stations that don't have a Presto Card reader.     Unbelievable.

Burning biomass is an idiotic system that only makes sense to those that think the value of a forest is solely based on board feet of timber.  It's WAY PAST time to look for alternative materials for building such as hemp, bamboo, repurposed materials and reducing the size of homes, businesses, etc.  Time is quickly running out before runaway climate change destroys civilization and wipes out over 75% of all species.  Forests sequester carbon- wake up, Oregon.

Comment: Now with state-by-state winner-take-all laws (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), Wyoming, like 23 of the smallest states, is politically irrelevant in presidential general elections.

In 2012, 24 of the nation's 27 smallest states received no attention at all from presidential campaigns after the conventions. They were ignored despite their supposed numerical advantage in the Electoral College. In fact, the 8.6 million eligible voters in Ohio received more campaign ads and campaign visits from the major party campaigns than the 42 million eligible voters in those 27 smallest states combined.  

The 12 smallest states are totally ignored in presidential elections.  These states are not ignored because they are small, but because they are not closely divided “battleground” states.

Comment: My doctorate is in psychology. From that perspective, I caution against applying such simplistic experimental setups to the real world exercise of power. Experimental psychology, in my not-so-humble opinion systematically fails at fairly "operationalizing" (devising experimental conditional that get at deep psychological notions such as, here, the corrupting power of authority). Although I only read the abstract in your reference, this type of experimental setup fails to take into account the white coat effect of the experimenter's instructions. 

To be clear, I agree 100% with Lord Acton's observation, which, as I am sure you know, was made with respect to Pius IX and Vatican I; but the truth of that statement of a "powerful human tendency" is a far cry from affirming that "power always corrupts." 

Acton's full quote was "Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely." The two words "tends to" are the key to whole hearted affirmation of the great wisdom herein.

Comment: In my opinion opening the bank account should occur around the same time the allowance starts.  As the column notes the accounts don't cost anything, and the lessons from just visiting the bank at a young age and making deposits will be an invaluable lesson.  Sure the interest rates these days don't amount to anything but neither do piggy banks.  It is more the mental exercise that saving money for the future is a good thing to do.

I don't buy into the allowance concept as I think it generally instills more bad habits than good.  Sure it teaches about budgeting but usually only from the perspective figuring out how to get your wants.  It doesn't teach anything about needs and savings all depend on the child or the influence of the parent. 

I think you can teach as much about budgeting and financial know-how by introducing them over time to your daily financial responsibilities.  Starting out with basic concepts and graduating to more complex items in line with their abilities.

Comment: In much of the developed world (i.e. the OECD) inflation-targeting has been the core objective of monetary policy ever since inflation laid waste to government planning and projections when it degenerated into the stagflation of the 1970s when growth stalled and  inflation ballooned out past 20%. This erodes savings and investment and it encourages borrowing and spending. The $20000 object which you borrowed to buy today (at 20% interest p.a over 5 years) was likely to cost you $100 000 cash in 5 years time, so it made sense to borrow now. Besides, you'd probably get double-digit pay-increases every year anyway, so the principal you'd borrowed was shrinking as a percentage of your income.
Today OECD nations have reined in inflation so well (sitting around 1% p.a.) that they are now in danger of slipping into an even more destructive force: deflation. SA's inflation (near 7%) is still way too high to worry about deflation, so it needs to be hauled down lower.

Comment: The laws read "least restrictive appropriate educational placement".  This doesn not mean persistent disruptive behavior must be tolerated.  It does mean a district must have a "cascade" of services available and place a student in the "least restrictive" one.  It may mean a "special" class for disruptive, dysfunctional students as a "take-out" alternative...if the student is disruptive he/she is sent to the alternative classroom and returned to regular classroom attendance when the alternative staff feels appropriate.  It may mean a "full time" alternative class placement (on campus) with the student attending regular classrooms as he/she demonstrates the ability to handle such placements.  There are additional options, home instruction and even residential treatment placement paid by the district.  However, districts can't just "dump" a student back home and have a tutor stop by a few times a week or whatever......

Was there hazing or stuff done to excess? Um, absolutely. Albeit nothing that could compare to the first month of parenthood or having to deal with a ridiculous coworker or living through a loved one fighting a terminal illness. In other words, life is messy. As an adult you have to make decisions about how to get through the messiness as well as who you want to be and how you want to live and be remembered. Comment: With regards to Arctic ice cover, there are very different measures of how much ice there is. One measure is sea-ice extent which, as the name implies, is a measure of coverage of the ocean where ice covers 15% or more of the surface. It is a two-dimensional measurement; extent does not tell us how thick the ice is. The other measure of Arctic ice, using all three dimensions, is volume, the measure of how much ice there really is.

All data shows an obvious trend over the space of a decade or more, showing a decrease of about 5% of average sea-ice cover per decade.  It is clear from the various data sets, terrestrial and satellite, that both the sea ice extent and multi-year ice volume are reducing. Sea ice extent recovered slightly during the Arctic winters of 2008-09, but the full extent of annual ice reduction or gain is seen in September of each year, at the end of the Arctic summer. The volume of multi-year ice has not recovered at all, and is showing a steeply negative trend.

But this doesn't excuse what the NDP are doing.  Alberta lived too high on the hog for too long, and got fat and complacent. Comment: I see the parks as something we, as in all of the citizens of America, own. Because of that I believe they should largely be maintained with tax dollars and fees should be kept affordable so all of us can go and visit. They're our national treasures.

Converting all of the operating expenses and maintenance into fees will just stunt tourism. Tourism, for most of our parks, is a huge source of sales-tax revenue in those states - not to mention all the ancillary jobs these locations help to support. Without easy and affordable access, it could both stunt our local economies and make it nearly impossible for people of lower incomes to visit... so, yeah, I support subsidizing our parks maintenance. I don't find that extreme in the least & think it's a good thing for all involved.

Comment: PEI starts voting next week to change their electoral system and it very likely may go to MMP which is probably the most ideal type. FPTP to elect their local MLA but with a portion of members elected based on their share of the total vote. This allows people who voted for the Green Party for instance to actually have representation. This is what I, a small l liberal/moderate, think is best federally even if that means more minorities. The way I see it is that the parties should be able to find common ground on many issues and work together and for the ones that don't then they will be seen as childish and turfed come the next election cycle. Too often parties oppose just because they are partisan and don't look for the best interest of the voters. I will vote for any party, left or right, if they have good ideas and that's how most Canadians are. I won't vote for sheep like the previous MPs under Stephen Harper or those who oppose just because they don't like the other party.

Comment: I am in fact to the manor born. 
Ok, I was born in rural Ct, in a small place with an outhouse and no running water. Mother had to go to a pump on a small hill just outside the place. It was a summer cottage near a lake. But since I didn't know the difference, it was a manor to me. Stayed there until I was in second grade. 
Perhaps a barbarian doesn't really know there is another way to behave until it is pointed out. Of course, as in the case of Rome, such do-gooders sometimes ended really badly. 
This country had a really superior person, Jimmy Carter, as President. The media seems to go out of its way to ridicule his "silly" peacemaking.
I may be wrong and there may be an afterlife, and if there is, I want to go wherever Jimmy Carter ends up. He is a truly gentle caring person of intelligence. 

Hugh

Comment: This article is completely wrong on a number of counts.
These convertible debentures are equivalent to selling stock. They are not debt even though they are called debentures. The debenture/installment structure is used to provide an attractive yield on the deal.  They will turn into stock when the deal is completed. Fortis used the same structure.
The stock did not fall because  a few analysts may not like the deal. It fell at the open because the company just sold approx $1.4 billion of stock into the market. Simply supply and demand- they had to sell the stock at a discount to get it out the door. The sale price is indicated at $21.40 in the details of the offering.
The stock is now basically unchanged from yesterday's close - $22.53. That indicates that the market likes the deal, otherwise the stock should be trading $1.00 or more lower.
Poorly written article with little understanding illustrated by the authors. One can safely assume they didn't even read the press release.

Comment: "A well regulated militia being necessary to a free State, the right of the People to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed."  By stating that "in addition" to calling for a militia the second amendment also called for the right to keep and bear arms, the author repeats the error that most 2nd amendment proponents fall into.  In fact these are not separate clauses - the second amendment is all one sentence, and it is all about the States rights to have an armed militia.  It was well understood at the time that the states were concerned about the constitution giving the federal govt. sole authority and responsibility for standing up a national army, and insisted on the right of states to maintain armed militias be enshrined in law.  This was especially true for slave states that feared that their slave hunting militias would be disbanded by the Feds.  Look at the wording of "bear arms"  You don't "bear arms" at the shooting range - you bear arms in battle.

Comment: Let me explain why I have a problem with anyone in power who says "we cannot cut the state budget," or "we can't cut our way out of this hole." The taxes proposed will require me to cut 15% or more of my income.  I am in the working poor. My family of 3 has an income around $30,000 a year. The proposed taxes and taking of half our dividend check will take about 15% of my income; the 24 cent a gallon gas tax will cost about $500 a year, the income tax likely won't take much, the tire tax will take $600. (studs for 2 vehicles) Property taxes and home insurance both rose this year, taking another 3% of my income. If I choose not to stud up my two vehicles, I compromise the safety of my family. Not an option.  So why is it that my legislators claim they cannot find any cuts, but they think I and all other Alaska residents can make the cuts in our budgets just fine? My income in the private sector has been stagnant for 5 years. Meanwhile, state employees' incomes have gone up 3% per year.

Comment: Up until a couple of years ago, Canada was actively promoting asbestos to the developing world. We knew it killed Canadians, but we were okay with it killing them. It wouldn't mean rampant removal at all. But it would mean proper safeguards for removal workers, which are not in place today.

Comment: These are valid points and I largely agree - just looking at rates of use of force without controlling for other relevant variables may suggest that a problem exists, but this report does not conclusively demonstrate that the is a problem.  I think the report was competently done as far as it went, but it simply didn't take the analysis to it's logical conclusion.  It looks like there was sufficient data to do tests for significance and control for exogenous variables, but nothing was done in this area.

Still, the response from the Sheriffs office is disappointing to me.  The letter from current research staff is vague and looks like an attempt to stonewall or disavow the report.  They make no attempt to enlighten anyone about the limitations of the study, but seem to attempt to discredit it.

Comment: Assuming the president has the unmitigated ability to terminate a federal investigation, how would that play out in the following scenario?

I'm using this absurd scenario to illustrate the lunacy of investing unmitigated powers into a single office. But if Professor Dershowitz has a response, I would love to hear it.

These are people who can never be persuaded by rational argument - so extreme and entrenched is their ignorance. 

Unfortunately the alt-right are mirrored by on the left by a group that is overly myopic, irrational and obsessed. These people hold, for example, that any immigrant is a good immigrant and that we must accept everyone who claims to be a refugee. This mentality has created division in the U.S. and even more tension in the E.U. where unchecked immigration and porous borders gave way to Brexit and may presage a resurrection of fascism. 

The general case should be decided on the numbers, which are lacking. But there's no shortage of anecdotal evidence that accommodation can go too far.

Comment: "You are aware the budget in operation down south was passed by the previous administrations?"

No actually it isn't.  The previous Congress didn't even pass a budget for the 2017 fiscal year, that ended Sept. 30th.

In the U.S. the President "writes" the budget but it is up to Congress to pass (or not pass) the budget and what Congress passes might have little to no relation to what the President wrote.  With a Republican Congress the budgets "written" by Obama were largely tossed in the trash (much like what happened when George W. Bush was President with a Democrat Congress for fiscal 2008 and 2009).

For the now-finished 2017 fiscal year the previous Congress only passed "continuing resolutions" while the budget was actually passed by the current Congress, partway into the fiscal year.

For the current 2018 fiscal year the budget was written by President Trump and passed, with relatively few changes, by the current Congress.

Comment: Circumstantial at the moment, but a very powerful correlation.  The average temperature of bodies of water are increasing, warming earlier than in years past.  This provides a longer season for the cyanobacteria to thrive.  Warmer water equals more blooms, longer blooms.  A fraction of a degree of warming can make a big difference.

We need to be at least concerned and cautious about this.  There is a significant, and growing body of evidence that exposure to low-level cyanobacteria toxins are implicated in motor-neuron disease (ALS, Lou Gehrig's Disease).  A lot of communities draw their water from lakes and streams that could be vulnerable to these changes.  I recall Dunes City on the coast having a big problem from a bloom in Siltcoos Lake.  Data suggests that this could be more frequent in the years to come.

Comment: I managed to overcome some of my childhood dislikes - actually to the point that many people regard me as an adventurous eater.  Not true since the adventurous side of me only extends to meat and fish.  I think a lot of the people that think I'm adventurous are basing that on watching me at a sushi bar (where I'm always willing to try pretty much any type of seafood they have) or in chinese restaurants where I'll eat just about any meat dish, no matter how unusual it may be to anglo palates.

But I still avoid veggies like the plague.  And two things I won't even consider eating are tomatoes and cucumbers (ironically I love pizza but that's as close to tomatoes or tomato sauce as I'll come).  As for cucumbers, I admit I've never even tasted one but there is something about the smell that starts my stomach churning - wave a cut one under my nose and I'll start vomiting.

Comment: The "wrong" if you want to call it that regards two problems in the urban environment, the growing urban heat island + increased urban storm runoff on impervious surfaces. Both cause problems for city dwellers. Our cities  hotter than nearby less developed areas, increasing electrical costs by all users. Storm runoff requires infrastructure to manage even small storm events, driving up costs to taxpayers. Mitigating these with green roofs would benefit the health + pocketbooks of the taxpayers + it makes sense to offer incentives to developers + building owners as well. Other benefits could include ones I mentioned previously; an increase in livable space, such as parks,community gardens + urban farms atop certain structures. Chicago, New York + much of Europe is decades ahead of us on this concept. 

Here is a link to view Denver's largest green rooftop above the Denver:
http://www.mundusbishop.com/mordecai-childrens-garden-at-denver-botanic-gardens.html

Comment: Nice job cherry picking projects that support your view. Other cities, like Seattle, have shown dramatic growth in ridership. There are numerous cities with similar stories of ridership increases. You just seized on a couple that don't because you oppose rail.
There are other factors that affect transit ridership, including the service areas (do the trains/buses go where you want to travel), cost of gasoline (expense of alternatives), movement of work places from the urban core, etc. Populations, jobs and business locations are not static. Systems that adapt to changes will show better ridership.

Comment: This is an interesting attempt to kickstart an ecosystem in a region with a staid business culture that's never had a huge start-up success (Blackberry was K-W).

But calling business judgment "the scarcest input" is wilfully ignorant. The scarcest input is clearly smart, dedicated people who are lucky enough to have the right idea at the right time and driven enough to pursue it against all odds. It's a wise move to connect driven creators to business advice, but the *truly* scarce resource is a Larry Page or a Steve Jobs.

Putting people who exhibit that potential in a nurturing environment is a good idea. Connecting them with business advice and contacts is a much easier task – as the existence of this program illustrates.

Sadly, I think this op-ed tars a good idea with the taint of a classic biz-school mistake: management believing they're more important than the problem-solving, creating employees who add the most value.

Comment: It already is the case that if you start taking your pension early, you get a lower annual payment. And let's face it, the people taking it early, like the people who keep working, tend to be from the upper income brackets or to have secure pensions as teachers do. I find it puzzling that we are working with actuarial tables instead of doing the obvious. Canada had an advantage over places like the US, in that the largest age cohort was born between 1955 and 1965. They were in their thirties and forties when Foot's Boom, Bust, Echo came out. Ten years ago it was possible to make defined benefit pensions compulsory for companies over a certain number of employees. Much more of the aged population would have been able to support themselves in the coming years.  Even now, that age cohort has between five and fifteen years to work. The government could sell units in a defined benefit plan as an alternative to RRSPs, with large employer participation required.

Comment: Employer provided drug benefits are critical to the health of millions of Canadians contributing over $10 billion in 2014 according to the Canadian Life and Health Insurance Association. Private benefit plans have helped offset the cost of public programs and serve other employer purposes, such as keeping employees and their dependents well and at work. Increasing business taxes for health and dental benefits will only serve to reduce employers' ability to continue coverage due escalating drug cost from expensive specialty drugs such as biologics. The insurance industry is unlikely to continue to provide risk protection for annually recurrent high cost drugs as incidence and expense increase with new medications. Provincial drug plans are also at a tipping point as cost thresholds are exceeded. These very same plans will however, become the fallback as more employer plan cost surpass their own thresholds with drug benefits either restricted or eliminated. 

Be careful what you ask!

Comment: I do recommend it. The first season (available in its entirety on Netflix) focuses on the very young Elizabeth and her struggle to reconcile personal desire with official responsibility. She's surrounded by all these characters with varying degrees of either stoicism or petulance, each trying to push her in one direction or another. It's fascinating to watch how she navigates it all.

Two outstanding acting jobs to look for. One is John Lithgow (yes, a yank!) as Winston Churchill. He's a little over the top at times, but ultimately he brings a touching vulnerability to his portrayal of the aging PM. 

The other is Alex Jennings as the Duke of Windsor, the former Edward VIII. His scenes with Claire Foy’s Elizabeth are touching. Jennings plays him as a man who understands that the tragedy of his life is that he chose desire over duty, and that hers is that she’s done the opposite.

Season 2 coming in November.

Comment: These are some solid questions so early in the morning!   Let me try to answer. 

If our principles and actions are in opposition to God's will eventually there will be discordance and pain in us or around us.  Consider the alcoholic, the anorexic, the porn addict or the prideful self-serving CEO. Thus, principles must = Good. 

There may be some moments of 'high' or relaxation, but there will follow problems, pain, discomfort.

In this case our intentions and princples run against the true good - God's will - and so what will follow will be either disaster in and around us, or a life of "highs and lows", with a downsloping, empty life, one without meaning and joy.

It is a joy to be close to God. We seek virtue (or seek to remove vices) in order to help us be closer to God and do His will.

The feeling we (sometimes, often) get from growing in virtue or being virtuous or good should not be sought in and of itself, but rather we do good to serve God and love Him, not for + self-regard

Comment: An interesting idea.

"Louisiana would replace its six single-winner districts that are now locked down for five Republicans and one Democrat with two competitive multi-winner districts each with three seats."

And Oregon has four Democrats and one Republican.  And unlikely to change in our lifetimes, except maybe to pick up one more Democrat.   

Why would either Oregon or Louisiana want to change?  

Enthusiasm for giving up political power is notably missing from both major political parties, whether in Oregon or elsewhere.

Clearly a pie-in-the-sky concept in this country!

Comment: God bless Father Riehl. My wife and I drive an hour each way to attend, revere and celebrate the Latin Mass in Charlotte. We are considering moving to Waynesville, specifically because the Latin Mass is celebrated at St. John's. The news report failed to include in the story that the Latin Mass is celebrated at St John's once a week on Wednesday evening. The eight other weekly masses are celebrated as Novus Ordo, including two Spanish Masses. Apparently one traditional Latin Mass per week is enough to drive some "Catholics" out of the pews, and in some cases into Protestant churches. Incidentally, this story is about two years old, and is routinely resurrected from the mothballs whenever it seems necessary to diminish, marginalize and otherwise slur those who find holiness and solace in the traditional Mass. Tolerance too often works only in one direction.

Comment: Vermont ditched it because they didn't have a good way to fund it. Their small population doesn't have the purchasing power to affect drug prices or much of anything else, which was a large part of the problem. The other part is that they were only planning to tax in state companies and not out of state companies who do business there, so the tax burden was substantially higher on everyone in the state. 
Much of the savings from single payer come from the ability to negotiate with the private companies offering healthcare and prescriptions. Vermont wasn't able to do either so they scrapped it at the last minute.

Comment: To call the initiative and referendum process "interesting" and then immediately start talking about its "problems" shows either a lack of knowledge of the history of initiative and referendums or opposition to them feigning neutrality. A counter argument goes like this if voters are qualified to elect representatives we are certainly as qualified to determine public policy by selecting legislation that their representatives may not want or perhaps have been monied/lobbied against.  A better place to look would be Switzerland for how initiatives and referendums work over time. You are either for democracy or you are not. Indirect democracy [electing representatives] doesn't work out so well if one is to judge by the current state of affairs. I'd much rather vote directly on proposed legislation than vote in a selection of someone to vote on legislation. Cut out the middle man and the "middle man's" profit i.e. campaign contributions. cheers.

Comment: Okay, but be sure to tell your privately obtained firewood to burn clean or be sure that the dirty smoke from your green wood or inadequate stove remains on your property. Once that dirty smoke crosses your property line, it is in the public domain. When your smoke drifts onto my property and into my lungs, when do my private property rights (including my body) equal yours? 
This problem shouldn't be so hard to resolve! Asking neighbors to burn responsibly, and even offering a very lucrative stove change out carrot, isn't requiring people to change their way of life. New stoves burn way more efficient and cleaner. Haven't met anyone who has regretted upgrading. I don't support fining people, as it seems to fuel the fear-mongers' story. I appreciate the concern of government overreach. I haven't hesitated knocking on doors as a private citizen and will continue to do this. Comment: Protection of health and safety always has a cost.   When there is a serious injury at a public facility, a lawsuit can result in changes that protect the public safety and can help prevent the reoccurrance of dangerous conditions that can result in injuries or death.   In Mexico, an outside basketball court at a school can be built on a hill where if you run off the court chasing the basket ball, you can fall off a 5 - 7 foot concrete wall and get seriously injured (I know, I have personally seen at least one of these in Mexico).  If someone gets hurts in Mexico on this type of dangerously defective basketball court, its all on you, because there is no way to hold anyone accountable.  Hence, no reason to make anything safer.   Here in the United States you would never see that type of risk being taken, because the owner of the facility can be sure that they will be held accountable for any injuries or deaths that result from the negligent design of even a basketball court.

Comment: On the proposed Security Council resolution...

Russia vetoed it for obvious reasons, the main one being that it apportioned blame prior to any investigation. However, there were other important reasons. The resolution said inspectors chosen by the UN and the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) must be given prompt and unrestricted access to any and all Syrian government sites they choose, provided with flight plans and logs they request, and given the names of military officers in command of any aircraft. Damascus would also have to arrange meetings, including with generals or other officers, within no more than five days of the date on which such meeting is requested. 

Now get this: in the event of non-compliance with any of those terms, Syria would be subject to military action mandated by the UN Security Council.

As for the terrorist group that made the accusation? It had to provide delay-free and safe access to the site of the reported incident, only.

Comment: Republicans failed because they didn't take the time to put something forward that was a real improvement. Just several slap-dash efforts of crafting a bill in a couple of weeks with no real review or discussion with patients, doctors, insurers, etc. And no thinking out of the box.

I read about an idea that I think has merit. Put your partisan blinders up (and I'm sure this idea has flaws all its own), but I think it's a good starting point: Single-payer for all with something like a $50K deductible (no one knows what the real number should be, so for right now $50K is a placeholder). The government covers you for all expenses above $50K. Below that, you are on your own. Pay out of pocket or find an insurance to cover you below $50K. Totally free market and unregulated, with premiums no worse than car insurance. If you don't get that insurance, you can't bankrupt out of your medical bills. In essence, it combines a lot of what Dems want and Repubs want. And unties it from employers.

Comment: I would recommend they hire someone to research officers' everyday work and develop a fitness test that reflects what would generally be required in the course of their duty.

The main issue with generalized "fitness" tests is they'll use place-holder activities to try to gauge ability without recognizing that performance on those tasks may be influenced by factors other than what they're claiming to measure. Ex: arm/ab strength being equal, push-ups will be harder for females due to the different center of gravity/weight distribution. For similar reasons, it's easier to hip-throw/trip/unbalance a male if you're doing grappling/take-down exercises. A test where people have to carry a heavy pack puts females at a disadvantage, even with strength and endurance being equal, if the packs were designed with a male form in mind and the weight distribution and shape of the pack was not adjusted as needed. Etc. Ideally, you would have sets of tasks people could select from to show aptitude.

Comment: Joanne, under ACES, a company could recover only 25% of their losses. Currently under SB21 that rate has increased to 35%. 

Those loss recovery percentages are the “FLAT” tax rates for their respective oil tax schemes.  It seems clearer now why the SB21 proponents were adamant with the 35% FLAT TAX MANTRA. If prices dropped, their losses could be recovered at the higher rate of 35%.

At $50 oil, the effective tax rate drops down close to 12% under SB21, after deducting the $8 production tax credits, NOT the so called 35% FLAT TAX RATE. However, under SB21 they can recover a carry forward loss at the higher 35% “Flat” tax rate.

Americans, in large numbers, feel that the current political system is failing them and that both parties are equally responsible.  And really, can you blame them?  American's national debt is spiralling out of control.  Median wages in the country have stagnated ever since the 'dot.com' bubble burst in 1999 while median wages in many other countries, including Canada, have risen steadily for 2 decades now.  Politicians largely seem increasingly out of touch with what is happening on the ground.

The result?  Obama came in campaigning on 'Real Change' and won some of the most lopsided elections in decades, though whether he delivered is questionable at best.  Sanders and Trump came in promising actual change while Hillary Clinton came in promising the status quo, and people voted for change.

Whether Trump will deliver change, and what that change will look like, is still up in the air.

Comment: The SCC didn't say they "wanted" an abortion law, they just said it was possible to regulate late-stage abortion without offending the Charter. There's no need for the state to regulate when they've already authorized the CMA to regulate the profession, and when the CMA has already regulated abortion in accordance with the Charter ruling.

Comment: John- I served in the 1991 Gulf War and was part of  the forces that invaded Iraq as the left hook force. That war was short, brutal, and I had no issues. 
On December 7, 2003, I was notified that I was going to be sent to Iraq once more! On March 17, 2004, I arrived at LSA Anaconda/Balad Air Base nicknamed Mortaritaville.That was my base of operations and in that 11 months, I almost lost my life 3 times and numerous other occasions, where I witnessed rockets, remote IEDS vehicle borne IEDs, and mortars. 
In 2005, I came back to America, my mother and my late wife said I was ANGRY! Those who have faced horror will never forget and will not entirely get over it. 
 Like the Robert deNiro Character in the movie ,The Mission,  I am in constant internal debate about violence. Personally, I would use violence as the last resort.
Still, we do need the military and police forces. Because as many of us know, it's not kumbaya and sadly, violence has to be used to stop a bad person or situation.

Comment: JH prefaced all of that with "if you're still that worried about a potential "market disaster"".....in other words if you're an emotional investor more concerned with short-term results vs. building wealth over the long term and want to guess what the market might do, then maybe you could let your cash dividends accumulate for some unknown period of time and hope to use that small amount of money to buy more stocks a) if the market does correct, historically less than 50/50 odds but let's call it 50/50 and b) you use that accumulated cash to buy at or near the bottom of the decline (very unlikely) but let's very optimistically call that 50/50 as well. This extremely optimistic 0.5 x 0.5 = 25% odds, most would agree isn't a logical approach to investing. 
On the other hand, if you are simply allowing 4% or even 5% of your portfolio aside (your portfolio's dividend yield) and it allows you to experience less stress over your portfolio, go ahead, it's no big deal. Not like having 60%cash

"Of the current crop, Jagmeet Singh is clearly the gimmickiest, their latest quick ticket to power: GQ spread, martial arts, colourful headgear. It’s not that he has no ideas. perhaps in imitation of the protestant practice the church in the usa came to call the ordained head of the parish pastor. the language of church law calls such a priest " parish priest" parochus.

since the issue at hand is church titles , hope this observation is to the point.
also it is worth observing that the american church has unique practices.

we are out of step with most of the church in this area of clerical addresses and historically our use of the title father for secular priests is an anomaly

Comment: ...all I know is, we can't keep dwelling on the past. History happened, we can look back with decades of hindsight and point out wrongs that were committed and attempt to make corrections (which, in the future will be criticized by some experts not yet born with the gift of *their* hindsight), but the blame belongs in the past.  Holding on to a grudge - against people that are long, long dead isn't going to solve anything, certainly we will not move forward, looking over our shoulders, we will turn in circles. 

The Crown should negotiate honourably, fairly, and bend when the judiciary rules they were out of order. In a lot of cases the Crown is not doing that.  On the other side, First Nations need to face some grim realities - the sustainability of remote communities, the rampant social problems on reserves and the fact that the pre-Colonial way of life is never coming back. Holding grudges is hurting the next generation of First Nations people.
